subject: Communication
title: The Illusory Truth Effect
description: A short lesson to help you apply The Illusory Truth Effect.

hook.text: The Great Wall of China is visible from space. It isn't. But you've heard it so many times it feels true.

buildup.text: Hasher, Goldstein, and Toppino discovered that repeated statements are judged as more true â€” regardless of actual.

discovery.text: Repetition creates cognitive fluency â€” the brain processes familiar statements more easily, and ease of processing.

twist.text: The effect works even when people are told the statement is false. Repetition overrides explicit correction.

climax.text: This is why propaganda uses repetition. This is why corrections sometimes backfire.

punchline.text: Repetition doesn't make something true. It just makes it feel true.

quiz.question: What causes the illusory truth effect?
